Title: the allowance evaporation

Howard: We’re betting to see if Koothrappali can hold his breath longer than the disk can spin.
Yeah, we’re seeing if Raj can hold his breath longer than it.
Ha, you’re interested. You’re out ten bucks.
Come on, Raj, it’s like your favourite movie, you’re just Waiting to Exhale. Yeah, I knew you could do it.
And the car ride puts her to sleep.
Oh, no, now we have two.
You don’t need your dad’s money. You can get by on your salary.
Well, how much do you spend on food?
What, what are you doing? I, I, I schlepped the baby over, I brought imported beer. Why don’t you like me?
We are, that’s why I’m sad my best friend’s gonna be homeless.
Wait. Why are we talking about our place when Sheldon’s old room is sitting there perfectly empty?
Oh. How’s the dog gonna go to the bathroom?
Leonard: You can do this.
This is an Euler’s Disk. It’s a physics toy that demonstrates angular momentum, potential energy, and kinetic energy.
But Raj is from India, which means he’s no slouch at holding his breath.
How ya doing?
Dig deep, like when we bet you couldn’t fit into Howard’s pants.
Yes, he is.
Aw, that used to work with Sheldon.
Who forgot to crack the window?
Hey.
What’s going on with your dad?
But all you did was complain when he did that.
I’m sorry, is he waiting for someone to disagree?
I’m trying, but I’m judging.
Yeah. Well, we work at the same place as you, and we’ve always been fine.
Do you know how much your car costs?
Sounds like you’re gonna need a cheaper place to live.
Hey, you guys let Stuart live with you. Why not Raj, too?
What if he lives in your garage?
Yeah.
Oh, you brought your own lunch. Good for you.
What brought that on?
Sheldon: There’s no way.
Its weight and smoothness, along with the slight concavity of the mirror, means it can spin for a long time.
Kind of busy right now.
He’s not gonna make it.
You know, deep-sea divers holding their breath for several minutes have shown elevated markers of a protein that can signal brain damage.
It’s slowing down.
He’s not gonna make it.
Oh, I won’t. I only eat equilateral triangles. Isosceles, isosceles, oh, scalene. You didn’t see that.
Why?
I have multiple restraining orders that say otherwise.
If the judge couldn’t explain it to me, I don’t see how you will.
Hello.
Well, have a lovely evening.
If you think that’s more fun than talking to Zachary Quinto through a stall door, you’re crazy.
MSN Search, AltaVista, and Ask Jeeves. You?
Bert, I insist that you join us.
Not at all. Amy?
Well, I could deduce by his facial expression and body language that he was sad.
You want me to look at him and listen to him?
Actually, we met online.
Although, unlike your date, she actually showed up. Oh, he looks sad again.
No. No, I only told Leonard, Howard, Raj, Kripke, uh, Professor Wu, Professor Klein, and a lunch lady in the cafeteria. How everyone else found out is a mystery to me.
Why aren’t you talking to me?
Oh. Well, now I’m sorry I asked.
What is there to gossip about? We barely have one.
Is it safe to assume you’re not speaking to me again? If you’re not answering because you’re not speaking to me, perhaps we could come up with a signal. That works.
Well, wait. This is our first fight as a couple who live together.
I’m not sure of the protocol. Television teaches us that the man’s supposed to sleep on the couch, but of the two of us, you’re clearly more sofa-sized.
This isn’t fair. You’ve discussed aspects of our physical relationship with Penny.
That lady has a name. I don’t know what it is, but one time I accidentally called her mom.
(Knock, knock, knock) Amy? (Knock, knock, knock) Amy? (Knock, knock, knock) Amy?
Not exactly the welcome wagon, but I’ll take it.

I’m mapping basic topics of conversation and with whom they can be discussed. I call these circles zones of privacy. Don’t Google that unless you want to see pictures of people’s genitals. This circle contains only me and you. It represents subjects we only share with each other, details of physical intimacy, bathroom habits. Although, as I’m saying it, I may need to add Dr. Fink in here.
No, I was just excited to list him as a friend.
I’m sorry you were embarrassed. And now I understand that some things are just between you and me, and in the event of redness and swelling, Dr. Fink.
That’s reserved for thoughts I don’t share with anyone.
Of course.
No, they’re private.
A little.
Fine. Two years ago I got my driver’s license.
I like being chauffeured around. It makes me feel important.
No, you didn’t. But keep in mind, I felt extremely important.

Excuse me. May I have your attention, please? I have recently been made aware that my personal relationship with Amy Farrah Fowler has become water cooler gossip. And I just want to say, shame on all of you. We’re scientists. Our minds should be focused on the advancement of human knowledge, not the intimate details of other people’s lives.
Thank you, Bert. You’re a good man. That woman who stood you up and humiliated you last night really missed out.
Oh. Oh, I’m sorry. Correction, that woman not only had vigorous coitus with Bert, she also tipped him a dollar for a job well done. – That better?
All right, well, to sum up, focus on science, keep your nose out of other people’s business, and, uh, whoa, for a good time, call Bert.
Well, last night Amy was angry with me because I’d been foolishly telling people about certain personal matters.
Oh, I know that now. At first, I thought she was cranky because of her horrific menstrual cramps, but it turns out, no, she was genuinely mortified.
Penny: Aw, look at you watching sports.
Okay, I want in. Ten bucks says I’ll lose interest before that thing stops spinning.
Yeah, see, what’s happening here signals brain damage. My God, how long does this thing spin for?
You know, we could’ve come to you guys. You didn’t have to bring the baby here.
Yeah, until someone left him in the drugstore parking lot and he freaked out.
Oh, someone’s been shopping at Gucci.
And if you really want to hurt him, I look great in Chanel.
Wait, Leonard, he’s hurting. Let him feel how he feels.
Yeah. Shoes, I’m a seven-and-a-half, boots, I’m an eight.
All right, how much exactly does he pay for?
Yeah, women do like a man that can support himself.
All right, hang on. We can figure this out. Let’s just go over your expenses. How much is your rent?
You don’t how much your rent is?
Well, sometimes you can get free food and Wi-Fi from the neighbours. Just know you might have to marry one of ’em.
Raj, if you need a place to stay, of course you are welcome here.
Okay, only if you’re sure. Whew.
Amy: Hey, Sheldon, I found a great restaurant for date night.
The food here’s supposed to be great. Don’t fill up on chips.
Oh, look. It’s Bert, at the bar. We should go say hi.
Because that’s what you do when you see someone you know in a public place.
Sheldon, there’s a difference between greeting a friend and following a celebrity into a bathroom.
Sorry, I don’t have a list of defunct search engines that I miss.
Oh, no. Are you sure you don’t want to give her a few more minutes?
Sheldon, that was so sweet of you.
So the part where he got stood up didn’t clue you in?
Our-our first date was at a coffee shop.
Sheldon, it’s humiliating. Thanks to you, my colleagues are gossiping about our sex life.
I’m not sleeping on the couch because you don’t know what’s private and what’s not.
That’s different. She’s a close friend, not the lady in the cafeteria who cuts the crust off your sandwiches.
Are you really worried about revealing secrets to Stephen Hawking?
Well, I do appreciate you working on this.
What’s that little dot in the middle?
Interesting. You really have secrets you don’t tell me?
What? Why didn’t you say anything?
So when I got up at 4am. to drive you across the desert to an antique train museum, I didn’t have to?
Raj: And j, and just so you know, my favourite movie is Princess Bride.
Good, good. Uh, listen, I just wanted to let you know when you get my credit card bill, it might be a little high this month.
Oh, Daddy, you’re so rich and funny.
Uh, well, I was dating a woman at the university, but we broke up.
I know you are. That’s why you just bought me a new iPad. And before you start, I am not interested in you arranging a marriage for me.
You did?
What are you saying, that you’re giving up on me? What kind of father gives up on his son?
I can’t believe what I’m hearing. This is deeply hurtful.
Hello.
Yeah, I saw something for Halley and I couldn’t resist.
Yeah, it’s a crushed velvet baby cape.
Yeah, it was. But it’s my father’s money and I’m mad at him.
It turns out he doesn’t care if I’m married or if I’m single. He’s basically given up on me.
It is. He stopped trying to find Indian girls for me to marry.
Thank you, Penny.
My father thinks the reason I can’t make a relationship work is because I’m spoiled.
Just because he helps me out doesn’t automatically mean that I’m spoiled.
Okay, I’ll tell you, but please don’t judge me. He pays for my car, my rent, and my credit cards.
But Bernadette makes more money than Howard. She basically supports him.
Oh, please. Look in the mirror. You both look ten years older than I do.
I don’t want to say.
I don’t want to say because I don’t know how much it is.
My father pays for it. Do you know how much your rent is?
Well, then double it, because my building’s a lot nicer than this dump.
Not really.
The housekeeper does the shopping.
I’m spoiled? Your baby has a cape that costs $300.
I thought we were best friends?
Guys, I’m not living in a garage.
Thank you, but if I’m gonna just take advantage of my friends, I might as well keep on relying on my father.
Hello, Father. We need to talk.
I have come to an important decision. I will not be accepting your money any more. I’m a man, and I can take care of myself.
Yes, that is wonderful. You will no longer be able to accuse me of being spoiled.
Dad, I’m trying to tell you off, and you’re ruining it with your delight and relief.
Yeah, that’s right. Keep asking yourself that. But I still love you very much, so don’t cut me out of the will.
Yeah, I’m making a bunch of changes. This morning, I fired my dog walker.
Uh, I gave her an Imodium. That’s tomorrow’s problem.
Dr Koothrapalli (on skype): Hello, Rajesh. How are things by you?
Dr Koothrapalli: Well, you’re a grown man with a steady job. Why wouldn’t you spend all your father’s money?
Yeah. So what else is going on with your life?
Oh, I gave up on that a long time ago.
It’s too much work. You’re an adult who can’t get by without an allowance from his parents. Women don’t want that.
I have six children, five of whom are married and self-sufficient. I don’t think I’m the problem.
You’re also too sensitive. Women don’t want that either.
I am so proud of you.
Sorry. Oh, no, my grown son is going to stop spending all my money. Where did I fail as a father?
Bert: Oh, hey, guys. What brings you here?
I doubt it. I met her on G-Harmony. That’s a Web site for geologists to find love.
Yeah. Their slogan is we’re all about dating and not the carbon-14 kind.
Hey. Looks like I got stood up, so I’m gonna head out.
Nah, G-Harmony recommends after two hours, it’s time to cut bait.
Thanks. I’ll go grab a chair.
Good question. Let’s see. Infoseek, WebCrawler, oh, HotBot.
All right. How did you guys meet?
Well, I really envy your relationship. Other than you two only having sex once a year, you’re the perfect couple.
Uh, yeah, everyone at the university does.
He’s right. And I’m sorry for the part I played in this.
That doesn’t paint me in the best light.
Bernadette: Oh, it’s okay. It’s good to get out of the house.
Oh, I’m sure that’s not true.
Oh, my God, you really are spoiled.
When you moved here, you didn’t have a lot of money. How’d you get by?
I’m sorry, Raj. We really just don’t have the space.
